Authors: Sinn, C., Meissner, D., Memming, R.
Title: Charge transfer processes at WSe2 electrodes with pH-controlled stability
Affiliations: Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie der, Univ, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Sinn, Christian, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie der, Univ, Germany; Meissner, Dieter, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie der, Univ, Germany; Memming, Ruediger, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie der, Univ, Germany
Abstract: In aqueous solutions of low pH, the energy bands at the surface of n-WSe2 become unpinned upon illumination. The corresponding positive shift of bands is caused by accumulation of holes at the surface. This is understood as being due to a position of the corrosion potential positive of the valence band, which moves in a more negative direction with increasing pH. In acid solutions, the energy bands remain pinned under illumination in the presence of redox systems which have a standard potential located at or negative of the valence bandedge. Experiments with rotating ring disk electrodes have shown that in this case the electrode is completely stable. This is a very promising result with respect to regenerative solar cells, because for the first time a stabilization by a redox couple with a standard redox potential near the valence bandedge of a photocorroding n-type semiconductor was found. The charge transfer processes at n- and p-type electrodes are analyzed in detail in solutions of different pH.
Index Keywords: Semiconducting Selenium Compounds--Electronic Properties; Tungsten Compounds; Flatband Potential; Metal Dichalcogenides; Redox Couples; Semiconductor Electrodes; Tungsten Selenides; Electrodes, Electrochemical
Correspondence Address: Sinn, Christian; Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie der, UnivGermany

Authors: Meissner, D., Memming, R., Kastening, B.
Title: Photoelectrochemistry of cadmium sulfide. 1. Reanalysis of photocorrosion and flat-band potential
Affiliations: ISFH, Institut für Solarenergieforschung, Hannover, Sokelantstrasse 5, D-3000 Hannover 1, Germany; Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Meissner, D., ISFH, Institut für Solarenergieforschung, Hannover, Sokelantstrasse 5, D-3000 Hannover 1, Germany; Memming, R., ISFH, Institut für Solarenergieforschung, Hannover, Sokelantstrasse 5, D-3000 Hannover 1, Germany; Kastening, B., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Abstract: The photoelectrochemical behavior of cadmium sulfide depends strongly on the pretreatment of the electrodes. Sulfur, the main photocorrosion product of CdS, changes the potential drop across the Helmholtz double layer and shifts the flat-band potential of CdS in the anodic direction. Removal of sulfur from the surface is possible by prepolarizing the electrode at about -1.1 V(SCE) in the presence of oxygen. The flat-band potential of the clean (0001) Cd surface has been determined to about -1.8 V(SCE) in the dark. Illumination of the electrode leads to surface-state charging due to formation of S•-, the intermediate in the formation of both possible photooxidation products: S0 in the absence of oxygen and SO42- in the presence of oxygen. © 1988 American Chemical Society.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Photochemical Reactions; ELECTRODES - Surfaces; OXYGEN; SULFUR - Removal; CADMIUM SULFIDE; FLAT-BAND POTENTIAL; HELMHOLTZ DOUBLE LAYER; PHOTOCORROSION; PHOTOELECTROCHEMISTRY; SEMICONDUCTING CADMIUM COMPOUNDS
Correspondence Address: Meissner, D.; ISFH, Institut für Solarenergieforschung, Hannover, Sokelantstrasse 5, D-3000 Hannover 1, Germany

Authors: Meissner, D., Lauermann, I., Memming, R., Kastening, B.
Title: PHOTOELECTROCHEMISTRY OF CADMIUM SULFIDE. 2. INFLUENCE OF SURFACE-STATE CHARGING.
Affiliations: Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Meissner, Dieter, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger; Lauermann, Iver, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger; Memming, Ruediger, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger; Kastening, Bertel, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger
Abstract: The energy bands at the surface of clean CdS become unpinned upon illumination and are shifted in the anodic direction by several hundred millivolts. The same effect occurs in the dark after addition of the oxidized species of certain redox systems whose standard potentials are located in the bandgap of CdS. A model is presented in which the band movement is interpreted by positive charging of surface states. In the case of light excitation a hole in the valence band is captured by the surface state, in the case of a suitable oxidizing agent the surface state is charged by direct electron transfer from this state to the acceptor in the electrolyte. The potential dependence of photocurrents and dark currents can be explained semiquantitatively in terms of charge transfer via surface states.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; ELECTRODES - Surfaces; OXYGEN; BANDGAP; MINORITY CARRIER; PHOTOCURRENTS; SURFACE-STATE CHARGING; SEMICONDUCTING CADMIUM COMPOUNDS
Correspondence Address: Meissner, Dieter; Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger, Inst fuer Solarenergieforschung, Hanover, West Ger

Authors: Lauermann, I., Meissner, D., Memming, R.
Title: The problem of light-induced oxygen production at catalyst-loaded CdS suspensions
Affiliations: Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, D-2000 Hamburg 54, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lauermann, I., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, D-2000 Hamburg 54, Germany; Meissner, D., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, D-2000 Hamburg 54, Germany; Memming, R., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, D-2000 Hamburg 54, Germany
Abstract: It has been reported in the literature that oxygen is formed at catalyst-loaded CdS particles in alkaline media under illumination if hexachloroplatinate is used as an electron acceptor. In the present paper the mechanism of oxygen formation is analyzed in detail and it is proven that the oxygen is not produced by direct hole transfer from CdS via a catalyst to the solution. Various models are discussed and it is concluded that the catalytic effects are governed by the formation of metal-CdS Schottky junctions. The water oxidation is tentatively related to a platinum intermediate formed during light-induced reduction of the platinate at CdS. © 1987.

Authors: Meissner, D., Benndorf, C., Memming, R.
Title: Photocorrosion of cadmium sulfide: Analysis by photoelectron spectroscopy
Affiliations: Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Meissner, D., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Benndorf, C., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Memming, R., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Abstract: Photocorrosion of cadmium sulfide electrodes in aqueous electrolytes leads to sulfate formation in the presence and to sulfur formation in the absence of oxygen. All three sulfur species involved (S2-, S0 and SO2- 4) can be detected on CdS electrodes after treatment in photoelectrochemical cells using AES or XPS. Both, the S2p/3p XPS and the S Auger peaks are broadened on photoelectrochemical oxidized CdS due to deposition of elemental sulfur. The XPS binding energy of the S electrons is shifted by about 1 eV per sulfur oxidation step from around 161.5 eV for S2- to around 163.5 eV for S0 and around 168 eV for SO2- 4. The results obtained by photoelectron spectroscopy of electrodes transferred from the electrolyte directly into the UHV system without any cleaning and special precautions are in excellent agreement with the predictions based on photoelectrochemical experiments. For example, it could be proved by XPS that sulfur was transformed into sulfate in a reductive oxidation step in the presence of oxygen, leading to the CdS surface being cleaned of S0. © 1987.

Authors: Tubbesing, K., Meissner, D., Memming, R., Kastening, B.
Title: On the kinetics of electron transfer reactions at illuminated InP electrodes
Affiliations: Institut für Physakalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, 2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tubbesing, K., Institut für Physakalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, 2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Meissner, D., Institut für Physakalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, 2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Memming, R., Institut für Physakalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, 2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Kastening, B., Institut für Physakalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstr. 45, 2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Abstract: Various reactions at highly doped n- and p-type InP electrodes were investigated. Impedance measurements have shown that the flatband potential is changed upon illumination. The corresponding shift of the energy bands at the surface of InP was interpreted by the trapping of minority carriers in a surface oxide layer. The reduction and oxidation of various redox systems at p-InP were investigated in the dark and under illumination and it is shown that a thin oxide surface layer influences mainly the oxidation process. The results are compared with those obtained with GaAs and various charge transfer models are discussed in detail. © 1986.

Authors: Meissner, D., Memming, R., Kastening, B., Bahnemann, D.
Title: Fundamental problems of water splitting at cadmium sulfide
Affiliations: Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Hahn-Meitner-Institut für Kernforschung GmbH, Glienicker Strasse 100, D-1000 Berlin 39, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Meissner, D., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Memming, R., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Kastening, B., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität, Bundesstrasse 45, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Bahnemann, D., Hahn-Meitner-Institut für Kernforschung GmbH, Glienicker Strasse 100, D-1000 Berlin 39, Germany
Abstract: Oxygen is directly involved in the anodic photocorrosion of CdS leading to sulfate formation according to the overall reaction CdS + 4h+ + 2H2O + O2 → Cd2+ + SO2- 4 + 4H+. Sulfate formation leads to cleaning of the CdS surface from elemental sulfur and therefore improves the electrode behaviour dramatically. Removal of sulfur from the surface shifts the flatband potential of CdS to about -1.7 V(SCE) and the valence-band edge to -0.6 V(SCE). Accordingly holes lose their thermodynamic capability to oxidise water. © 1986.

Authors: Meissner, D., Memming, R., Shuben, L., Yesodharan, S., Graetzel, M.
Title: PHOTOCORROSION BY OXYGEN UPTAKE IN AQUEOUS CADMIUM SULPHIDE SUSPENSIONS.
Source title: Berichte der Bunsengesellschaft/Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
Affiliations: Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer, Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West, Ger, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Meissner, Dieter, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer, Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West, Ger, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West Ger; Memming, Ruediger, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer, Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West, Ger, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West Ger; Li Shuben, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer, Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West, Ger, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West Ger; Yesodharan, Seguna, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer, Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West, Ger, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West Ger; Graetzel, Michael, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer, Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West, Ger, Univ Hamburg, Inst fuer Physikalische Chemie, Hamburg, West Ger
Abstract: Photouptake of oxygen in aqueous CdS suspensions loaded with RuO//2 or R//2O//3 leads to the formation of sulphate and cadmium ions. This reaction constitutes also the dominant pathway in bare CdS suspensions.
Index Keywords: CADMIUM COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN PEROXIDE; OXYGEN; SUSPENSIONS; CADMIUM SULFIDE; OXYGEN UPTAKE; PHOTOCORROSION; CORROSION

Authors: Meissner, D., Memming, R., Kastening, B.
Title: CORROSION OF CdS-MONOGRAIN MEMBRANES USED FOR SOLAR-ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS.
Source title: Extended Abstracts, Meeting - International Society of Electrochemistry
Affiliations: Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger, Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Meissner, D., Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger, Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger; Memming, R., Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger, Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger; Kastening, B., Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger, Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger
Abstract: CdS is still one of the most promising semiconductor materials for direct conversion of solar into storable chemical energy. Detailed investigations of the published water splitting reaction were performed in the authors laboratory and have shown, that there are still many open questions concerning the oxidation reaction. Recent investigations of the corrosion of catalyst-loaded CdS suspensions used in oxygen photo-uptake experiments are in contradiction to the anodic dissolution of CdS which should lead to an increase of pH. However the authors observed a decrease of pH by irradiating aerated suspensions and therefore we predicted the formation of sulfate. 4 refs.
Index Keywords: CADMIUM COMPOUNDS; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS; SOLAR ENERGY; CADMIUM SULFIDE; DYNAMIC CAPACITY MEASUREMENTS; EXTENDED ABSTRACT; HELMHOLTZ LAYER; MONOGRAIN MEMBRANES; PHOTOCORROSION; MEMBRANES
Correspondence Address: Meissner, D.; Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger, Univ of Hamburg, Hamburg, West Ger

Authors: Meissner, D., Memming, R., Kastening, B.
Title: Light-induced generation of hydrogen at CdS-monograin membranes
Affiliations: Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität Hamburg, Laufgraben 24, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Meissner, D., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität Hamburg, Laufgraben 24, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Memming, R., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität Hamburg, Laufgraben 24, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany; Kastening, B., Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität Hamburg, Laufgraben 24, D-2000 Hamburg 13, Germany
Abstract: A new kind of membrane consisting of small particles of single-crystalline CdS embedded in a polymer film is described. In various photoelectrolysis experiments the properties of the membrane which separates a cell in two compartments were investigated. Relatively large quantities of H2 were produced in the presence of an electron donor such as S2- ions or EDTA and small quantities by direct photoelectrolysis of H2O. This technique gives information on the role of catalysts deposited on one or both faces of the membrane. © 1983.
